transcripts.text: You're probably talking about 50 or 100,000 gay members of the armed forces right now.  That's the reality.  They have functioned in the past.  In many instances, they have functioned with valor, with great courage.  Is it your suggestion that we throw everybody out of the military who is gay?
I worry about discriminating against people.  for any reason, whether it's economic or color.  But sexual preference is one I don't quite fully understand.  I haven't figured that out yet.

When people are dying, do you think you're going to look at the color of their blood or you're going to look at what their sexual orientation is after they've put their lives on the line?  I think not.  What we're talking about here is justice.  Do we judge men and women on their ability to do the job, to be good soldiers?  Or do we say to somebody, you're gay, you may not enter the armed forces.  Our economy is falling apart, we don't have national health care.  What we're talking here, to my mind, is a simple issue of justice and civil rights.  What America is supposed to be about is judge people on their ability to do the job, not on their sexual orientation.
